title: Integration and CLI Polish
description: Final integration work: store discovery (walk up directory tree to find .ctx/), consistent error formatting, end-to-end integration test covering the full workflow, and shell completion support.

title: Add store discovery (walk up directory tree)
description:
Create internal/store/discover.go:
- DiscoverStore() (string, error): starting from cwd, walk up parent directories looking for .ctx/
  - Return the path to the .ctx/ directory if found
  - Return error 'no context store found (run ctx init)' if reaching filesystem root
- Similar to how Git discovers .git/
- All commands except 'init' should call DiscoverStore() to find the active store
- Update all subcommands to use discovered store root instead of assuming cwd

This enables running ctx commands from subdirectories of a project.

title: Add consistent error formatting
description:
Review and standardize error output across all commands:
- All user-facing errors should be prefixed with 'error:' and printed to stderr
- Include actionable hints where possible (e.g., 'error: pack not found. Run ctx log to see available packs.')
- Exit codes:
  - 0: success
  - 1: general error (invalid input, not found, etc.)
  - 2: degraded result (e.g., replay degraded fidelity)
- No stack traces in user-facing output (log to debug mode only)
- Add --verbose flag to root command for debug output

title: Write end-to-end integration test
description:
Create a comprehensive integration test that exercises the full workflow:
1. ctx init → creates .ctx/ directory
2. ctx pack <test-log> → produces pack hash
3. ctx show <hash> → displays pack contents correctly
4. ctx replay <hash> → produces fidelity report
5. ctx diff <hash-a> <hash-b> → produces drift report (pack a second log for comparison)
6. ctx verify <artifact> → confirms provenance
7. ctx fork <hash> → creates draft
8. Finalize draft → new pack with lineage
9. ctx log → shows both packs

Use a temp directory for isolation. Include both happy-path and error cases. This test validates that all components work together correctly.

title: Context Pack Creation
description: Implement the Context Pack format: Go structs for the JSON manifest, execution log parsing, pack creation with content-addressed blob storage, canonical manifest hashing, and the ctx pack and ctx show commands.

title: Define Go structs for pack manifest
description:
Create internal/pack/manifest.go with Go struct definitions matching the JSON schema from design:

type Pack struct:
  Version, Hash, Created, Model, SystemPrompt (hash ref), Prompts []Prompt, Inputs []Input, Steps []Step, Outputs []Output, Environment, Parent (optional, for forked packs)

type Model struct: Identifier, Parameters map[string]interface{}
type Prompt struct: Role, ContentRef (hash ref)
type Input struct: Name, ContentRef (hash ref), Size int64
type Step struct: Index int, Type, Tool, Parameters map[string]interface{}, OutputRef (hash ref), Deterministic bool, Timestamp
type Output struct: Name, ContentRef (hash ref), ContextPack (hash ref)
type Environment struct: OS, Runtime, ToolVersions map[string]string

Include JSON tags for serialization. Add Validate() method to check required fields.

title: Implement execution log parser
description:
Create internal/pack/parse.go:
- ParseExecutionLog(path string) (*ExecutionLog, error): read and parse JSON execution log file
- Define ExecutionLog struct (raw input format before conversion to Pack manifest)
- Validate all required fields are present and well-formed
- On validation failure, return error listing ALL missing/invalid fields (not just the first one)
- Support reading from file path or io.Reader

The execution log is the raw input; the pack creation process converts it to the canonical manifest format with content-addressed references.

Spec: context-packs/Create a context pack from execution log (invalid log scenario)

title: Implement pack creation with blob storage
description:
Create internal/pack/create.go:
- CreatePack(store *Store, log *ExecutionLog) (*Pack, error): full pack creation pipeline
  1. Extract all content from log (prompts, inputs, step outputs, final outputs)
  2. Store each piece of content as a blob, collecting hash references
  3. Build Pack manifest struct with all content refs
  4. Serialize manifest to canonical JSON (sorted keys, no extra whitespace)
  5. Hash the canonical JSON to produce the pack hash
  6. Store manifest as a blob
  7. Register pack hash in .ctx/packs/ index

Canonical JSON is critical for deterministic hashing — same log must always produce same pack hash.

title: Drift Detection
description: Implement decision drift detection: structured comparison of two Context Packs producing typed drift entries (prompt_drift, tool_drift, param_drift, reasoning_drift, output_drift), JSON and human-readable output via ctx diff.

title: Define drift types and report structs
description:
Create internal/diff/types.go with:

type DriftType string constants:
  PromptDrift, ToolDrift, ParamDrift, ReasoningDrift, OutputDrift

type DriftEntry struct:
  Type DriftType
  Description string
  StepIndex int (optional, -1 if N/A)
  PackA interface{} (value from pack A)
  PackB interface{} (value from pack B)

type DriftReport struct:
  PackHashA string, PackHashB string
  Entries []DriftEntry
  HasDrift bool

Include methods:
  Report.JSON() ([]byte, error) for machine-readable output
  Report.Human() string for plain-text summary

Spec: drift-detection/Typed drift categories, Machine-readable diff output

title: Implement prompt comparison
description:
Create internal/diff/prompt.go:
- ComparePrompts(a *Pack, b *Pack) []DriftEntry
  1. Compare system_prompt hash refs — if different, emit PromptDrift entry
  2. Compare prompts arrays:
     - Align by index
     - For each pair, compare content_ref hashes
     - If different, emit PromptDrift entry identifying which prompt index differs
  3. Handle mismatched prompt array lengths (extra prompts in A or B)

Spec: drift-detection/Prompt changed between packs

title: Implement step comparison for drift detection
description:
Create internal/diff/steps.go:
- CompareSteps(a *Pack, b *Pack) []DriftEntry
  1. Align steps by index position
  2. For each aligned pair:
     - If tools differ → ToolDrift entry
     - If same tool but parameters differ → ParamDrift entry
     - If same tool+params but output_ref differs → ReasoningDrift entry
  3. Handle mismatched step counts:
     - Extra steps in B → reported as additions
     - Extra steps in A → reported as removals
     - Use ToolDrift type for step additions/removals

Spec: drift-detection/Typed drift categories (tool, param, reasoning), Step alignment for comparison

title: Implement output comparison
description:
Create internal/diff/output.go:
- CompareOutputs(a *Pack, b *Pack) []DriftEntry
  1. Build maps of output name → content_ref for each pack
  2. For shared output names: compare content_refs, emit OutputDrift if different
  3. For outputs only in A: emit OutputDrift (removed in B)
  4. For outputs only in B: emit OutputDrift (added in B)

Spec: drift-detection/Final outputs differ

title: Implement ctx diff command
description:
Wire up the 'diff' Cobra subcommand:

- Run all comparisons (prompts, steps, outputs)
- Aggregate DriftReport
- Default output: JSON (array of typed drift entries)
- With --human flag: plain-text summary describing each drift point
- Special case: same hash for both args → 'No differences found'
- Exit non-zero if either hash not found

title: Write tests for drift detection
description:
Create internal/diff/*_test.go with tests covering:
- Identical packs → no drift entries
- Different system prompts → prompt_drift
- Different user prompts → prompt_drift with index
- Different tools at same step → tool_drift
- Same tool different params → param_drift
- Same tool+params different output → reasoning_drift
- Different final outputs → output_drift
- Pack A has more steps than B → removals reported
- Pack B has more steps than A → additions reported
- JSON output is valid and parseable
- Human-readable output is descriptive text
- Non-existent pack hash → error

title: Deterministic Replay
description: Implement the deterministic replay engine: step-by-step re-execution, output hash comparison, three-level fidelity reporting (exact/degraded/failed), non-deterministic step handling, and dependency drift identification via ctx replay.

title: Define replay report structs
description:
Create internal/replay/report.go with:

type FidelityLevel string (exact, degraded, failed)

type StepResult struct:
  Index int, Tool string, Status string (matched/diverged/failed)
  ExpectedHash string, ActualHash string
  Deterministic bool
  Reason string (for failed steps)

type DriftEntry struct:
  Type string (tool_version, missing_input, environment)
  Description string
  Expected string, Actual string

type ReplayReport struct:
  PackHash string, Fidelity FidelityLevel
  Steps []StepResult
  Drift []DriftEntry
  StartTime, EndTime time.Time

Include methods: Report.Summary() string for human-readable output, Report.JSON() ([]byte, error) for machine-readable output.

title: Implement step executor for replay
description:
Create internal/replay/executor.go:
- ExecuteStep(step *Step, store *Store) (*StepResult, error): re-execute a single tool call
  1. Resolve tool by name (look up in registered tool map)
  2. Execute tool with recorded parameters
  3. Capture output, compute SHA-256 hash
  4. Compare against step.OutputRef
  5. Return StepResult with matched/diverged/failed status

For v0.1, tool execution is limited to file-system tools (read_file, write_file). Other tools return 'tool not available' failure.

Handle errors gracefully: if tool not found or execution fails, return StepResult with status=failed and reason.

title: Implement replay orchestrator
description:
Create internal/replay/replay.go:
- Replay(store *Store, packHash string) (*ReplayReport, error): full replay pipeline
  1. Load pack manifest from store
  2. Check environment: compare current tool versions against pack's environment.tool_versions, log drift entries for mismatches
  3. Walk steps array in order:
     - For deterministic steps: execute and compare output hash
     - For non-deterministic steps (deterministic=false): execute but divergence doesn't downgrade fidelity
  4. Compute overall fidelity:
     - exact: all deterministic steps matched
     - degraded: some deterministic steps diverged but all executed
     - failed: at least one step couldn't execute
  5. Collect drift entries (tool versions, missing inputs)

Spec: deterministic-replay/all requirements

title: Implement ctx replay command
description:
Wire up the 'replay' Cobra subcommand:
- Usage: ctx replay <hash>
- Load pack from store
- Run replay orchestrator
- Print replay report:
  - Overall fidelity (exact/degraded/failed) with color coding
  - Per-step results (matched ✓, diverged ≠, failed ✗)
  - Drift entries if any (tool version changes, missing inputs)
- Exit code: 0 for exact, 1 for degraded, 2 for failed
- Exit non-zero with error if hash not found

title: Context Sharing
description: Implement hash-based context sharing: ctx fork for deriving new packs with lineage, draft finalization, ctx log for listing packs, and ensuring portability (no absolute paths, no environment coupling).

title: Implement ctx fork command
description:
Create internal/sharing/fork.go and wire up the 'fork' Cobra subcommand:
- Usage: ctx fork <hash>
- Load existing pack manifest from store
- Create mutable draft:
  1. Copy pack manifest
  2. Add 'parent' field with original pack's hash
  3. Clear the 'hash' field (will be recomputed on finalization)
  4. Write draft to .ctx/drafts/<temp-id>.json
- Output draft location for editing
- Exit non-zero if source hash not found

The draft is mutable — user can modify prompts, inputs, steps before finalizing into a new immutable pack.

Spec: context-sharing/Fork a context pack

title: Implement draft finalization
description:
Add to internal/sharing/fork.go:
- FinalizeDraft(store *Store, draftPath string) (*Pack, error)
  1. Read draft manifest from .ctx/drafts/
  2. Ensure 'parent' field is preserved
  3. Store all content as blobs (in case new content was added)
  4. Compute canonical manifest hash (including parent field)
  5. Store finalized manifest as immutable blob
  6. Register in .ctx/packs/
  7. Remove draft file
  8. Return finalized pack with new hash

The parent field links the lineage — ctx show on the new pack should display the parent hash.

Spec: context-sharing/Forked pack records lineage

description:
Create internal/sharing/log.go and wire up the 'log' Cobra subcommand:

- Sort by created timestamp (newest first)
- Display one line per pack:
  - Hash (short form, first 12 chars), creation date, model identifier, step count
  - If has parent: show '(forked from <parent-short-hash>)'
- Default limit: 50 packs
- If no packs found: print 'No context packs found'

title: Object Store and Hashing
description: Implement the content-addressed object store (.ctx/ directory), SHA-256 hashing with sha256: prefix, blob storage with 2-char prefix subdirectories, deduplication, immutability, and the ctx init command.

title: Implement SHA-256 content hashing
description:
Create internal/store/hash.go with:
- HashContent(data []byte) string: compute SHA-256 and return in 'sha256:<hex>' format
- ParseHash(ref string) (algorithm string, hex string, error): parse a 'sha256:<hex>' reference
- ValidateHash(ref string) bool: check if a hash reference is well-formed

The sha256: prefix allows future algorithm migration. All content addressing throughout the system uses this module.

title: Implement blob storage with deduplication and immutability
description:
Create internal/store/blob.go with blob write operations:
- WriteBlob(root string, data []byte) (hash string, error): hash content, write to .ctx/objects/<2-char-prefix>/<rest-of-hash>
- Skip write if blob already exists (deduplication)
- Reject overwrite of existing blob with different content (immutability guarantee)
- Create parent directories as needed

Storage layout follows Git convention: objects/ab/cdef1234... where 'ab' is first 2 hex chars of SHA-256.

title: Implement blob retrieval with integrity verification
description:
Add to internal/store/blob.go:
- ReadBlob(root string, hash string) ([]byte, error): read blob from .ctx/objects/ by hash
- After reading, recompute SHA-256 and verify it matches the requested hash
- Return clear error if blob not found or integrity check fails
- BlobExists(root string, hash string) bool: check existence without reading

title: Implement ctx init command
description:
Create internal/store/init.go and wire up the 'init' Cobra subcommand:
- Create .ctx/ directory in current working directory
- Create subdirectories: objects/, packs/, refs/
- Create config.json with default configuration (version: '0.1')
- If .ctx/ already exists, report 'context store already initialized' and exit 0 (no error, no changes)
- Print success message with path to created store

title: Implement ctx verify command
description:
Wire up the 'verify' Cobra subcommand:
- Usage: ctx verify <artifact-path>
- Locate sidecar file (<artifact>.ctx.json)
  - If missing: report 'no provenance metadata' and exit non-zero
- Parse sidecar metadata
- Validate pack reference:
  - Look up context_pack hash in store
  - If not found: report 'provenance broken (pack not found)' and exit non-zero
- Content integrity check:
  - Hash the artifact file content (SHA-256)
  - Find matching output in pack's outputs by name
  - Compare hashes: report 'verified' or 'modified (expected: X, actual: Y)'
- Display provenance info:
  - Pack hash (suitable for ctx replay / ctx show)
  - Creation date from pack
  - Tools involved
  - Confidence and notes if present
- Exit 0 for valid provenance, non-zero otherwise
